content: H.R. 3962, Affordable Health Care for America Act, passed by the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009, is based on H.R. 3200. The Congressional Budget Office estimates the bill would reduce federal deficits by $109. The amendment proposed on November 3 reflects the enactment of H.R. 3548, the Worker, Homeownership, and Business Assistance Act of 2009. CBO projects the bill would reduce federal deficits by $109 billion over the 10-year period of 2010-2019 and insure 96% of the non-elderly, legally present U.S. population by 2019. The total cost of the coverage provisions, including Exchange subsidies, federal Medicaid expenditures, and tax credits for small employers, would be $1.052 trillion over 10 years, with a net cost of $891 billion after accounting for penalties and other issues. The net cost of the coverage provisions in the Affordable Health Care for America Act would be $891 billion over 10 years, offset by savings from other spending changes and increased federal revenues. This report outlines key provisions affecting private health insurance in the Act. The Affordable Health Care for America Act would increase federal revenues by $574 billion over the period. Key provisions include reducing the number of uninsured, restructuring the private health insurance market, setting minimum health benefit standards, providing financial assistance, and requiring individuals to maintain health insurance. H.R. 3962 would mandate individuals to have health insurance and employers to provide insurance or pay a payroll assessment. Market reforms like modified community rating and guaranteed issue would be implemented. Both mandates would be tied to acceptable health insurance coverage meeting minimum standards under a qualified health benefits plan. Coverage could be obtained through the Exchange or new employer plans. The Exchange, established under a new federal agency, would offer private plans alongside a public option. Subsidies for premium costs and cost-sharing would be available for individuals with incomes below 400% of the federal poverty level, but only through the Exchange. Other coverage options include Medicare and Medicaid. The bill would establish subsidies for individuals below 400% of the federal poverty level through the Exchange. Plans in the individual market could be grandfathered with no changes, and a CO-OP program would encourage non-profit health insurance cooperatives. Dental or vision plans would not be affected. The bill proposes the creation of non-profit health insurance cooperatives in the Exchange, effective from 2013. Revenues would be raised by limiting employer deductions and modifying tax-advantaged accounts. Background information on the private insurance market is provided to understand the reform proposed by H.R. 3962. The report summarizes key provisions affecting private health insurance in Division A of H.R. 3962, passed by the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009. Most provisions would be effective starting in 2013, with an Appendix showing the timeline for implementing provisions before 2013. The private health insurance provisions in H.R. 3962 are interrelated and include alterations to the current system. H.R. 3962 includes provisions to change private health insurance markets, focusing on individuals buying coverage directly or through small employers. If reform eliminates tools insurers use to guard against adverse selection, AHIP suggests individuals must be required to purchase coverage to prevent only the sick from enrolling. Americans obtain health insurance through various methods, including employment-based coverage, private sector options, and publicly funded programs like Medicare or Medicaid. In 2008, 60% of the U.S. population had employment-based health insurance, with employers choosing to purchase insurance or self-fund health benefits for their employees. Approximately 46 million Americans were estimated to be uninsured in 2008, with individuals and employers obtaining health insurance through various methods in the private market, including the large group, small group, and nongroup markets. More than 95% of large employers had employment-based health insurance. Large employers are able to obtain lower premiums for health insurance packages compared to small employers and individuals in the nongroup market due to economies of scale and a larger risk pool. They offer subsidies towards health insurance, attracting both healthier and sicker workers to enter the pool, resulting in a larger and more predictable risk pool. States have experimented with creating a single site for individuals and small employers to compare insurance plans and pool risk. While past experiments like California's PacAdvantage failed, states like Massachusetts have developed more sustainable models. Private-sector companies also help individuals compare health insurance plans. Less than half of small employers offer health insurance due to cost concerns and limited ability to spread risk. Insurers view small firms as less stable than larger pools. Small employers struggle to provide health insurance due to cost concerns and limited risk-spreading ability. Joining a larger pool, such as an Association or Exchange, could help small firms access better insurance options. States regulate the private health insurance market, with federal regulations mostly affecting employer-sponsored health insurance. Most states have premium rating rules for insurance carriers in small group and individual markets, ranging from pure community rating to adjusted community rating. Pure community rating means all enrollees pay the same premium regardless of health or age. Adjusted community rating allows pricing based on factors like age or gender. Only New Jersey and New York use pure community rating in nongroup markets, with New York also using it in the small group market. Federal law mandates that group health plans must restrict the period for excluding coverage of preexisting conditions. By December 2008, 42 states in the individual market limited exclusion periods for certain enrollees. States impose over 2,000 benefit mandates, while federal law mandates restrictions on preexisting condition coverage exclusion. Studies in 1999 and 2006 found that non-profits scored higher on key quality indicators.
